SEG.ORIGINAL_TEXT: Just today, gunmen burst into the headquarters of French magazine, Charlie Hebdo and murdered twelve people, including a number of journalists working for the magazine and two police officers.
I will wait for a couple of posts before I get started!
Before you get started? Doing what?

Before I get started with the posts, I will give the other Yelpers some time to comment so that they don't get the impression that I'm hogging the conversation. It happened just today, so all we have to do is to focus on the background: what have happened in the weeks, or months, or years before today's terrorist attack.

BACKGROUND: In 2011, Charlie Hebdo created controversy by creating portrayals of Muhammad, and that is what set them off, in part because it harkens back to the controversy in 2005 when Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten did editorial cartoons depicting Muhammad.

Bullshit, Bitter. ^^^ That magazine was free to satirize whatever the editors wanted. To Jews satire is a perfectly acceptable way of communicating.
One of the founders of Charlie Hebdo, was himself Jewish. Cartoonist Georges Wolinski was born in Tunisia to a Jewish mother, and Jewish-Polish father. He was an elderly man, shot and killed today.

Most of the political cartoonists killed today were rather elderly. Not only are their deaths tragic for obvious reasons, but they're irreplaceable. There are few effective political cartoonists left.

Sorry! I must have overlooked it. The two brothers were French-born, but France is not like what you would find in our country, USA.

In the US (and Canada), it is the country of the citizenry, without regard to ethnic group, and when they become US (or Canadian) citizen, they're one of us, the same as us, and culturally part of us cause American (and Canadian) democracy bounds us citizens together.

In France on the other hand, it is a country of the indigenous, with French being the major one, followed by Corsicans (related to Italians), Bretons (related to Welsh and Cornish), Occitans, Catalans and Basques (me having 6.25% Catalan and 12.5% Basque and are also found in Spain). When a foreigner (other Europeans included) received French citizenship,the indigenous would still regard naturalized citizens as perpetual foreigners since they have no cultural ties to the French culture. Personally, I have no objection to naturalized citizens in Europe cause like here, all it requires is knowing the native culture.
Noah, I think there are many people who do practice Islam peacefully. As an atheist, I'm not hugely in favor of any religion, especially not those that proselytize.

Having stayed in a number of countries where Islam is the majority religion, I came away with a favorable impression of the majority of people I met. Nevertheless, it's not a religion that encourages questioning or debate.

There are individuals from that religion who are themselves great thinkers and questioners. Often it takes a toll on them. If they remain within their own national boundaries it's not uncommon for them to be persecuted.

The fascist right were only interested in stirring up the fears of the French for votes, nothing else. It is right to condemn Islamist terrorist in the strongest forms, but it would never be fair to put the blame on a lot of Muslims just for the actions of only three. A few of the twelve dead were Muslims themselves, including one police officer.
Furthermore, you were talking about the right-wing party Front National, but it is not Jean-Marie Le Pen's Front National. Under his daughter

and new leader, Marine Le Pen, the party moderated and have the potential to attract well established minorities into the party, enough to become mainstream and disciplined, unlike the British National Party from UK.
Lawrence -- Yes. Everything I'm seeing now says he had an 18 month sentence. I think earlier I read he had a 2-3 year sentence and served 18 months of it.

Juan -- I'm not familiar with French law. If someone is born and raised in France, having never known any other country, can they be deported? I wouldn't think so. There are many 3rd generation Moroccans, Algerians, Lebanese ... even Tahitians.
I agree with you that the third generation were French citizens. Being a French citizen shouldn't be confused with being indigenous French.

As the son of Colombian immigrants, I sometimes have trouble in the past identifying with my fellow Colombian brethren, because they would view me as a gringo because I was whiter than most Colombians, but now my fellow Colombian diaspora accepted me now to the point that I am grateful to them for receiving me with open arms. I would even have an easier time getting Colombian citizenship because of my parents.

Proof that blasphemy isn't a sin- but massacring defenseless people definitely IS. Christians&Jews didn't get violent when Charlie Hebdo mocked their religions; they weren't offended. If you believe in an all-powerful God, He can put up with mere mortal mockery. Muslims need to man up&shut up when their religion is ridiculed... just like everybody else. They need to be desensitized to the concept of "blasphemy" if that's what it takes to prevent tragedies like this. If blasphemy offends you, pay it no mind. There are worse things in the world.
